discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Shaping is only used outbound

Selected Answer: C
Provided answer is correct.
From the book:
"In enterprise environments, traffic shaping is used to smooth the flow of traffic going out to the provider."
"Generally, policing is used to set the limit of traffic coming into an interface (ingress)" and "One example of using policing is giving preferential treatment to critical application traffic by elevating to a higher class and reducing best-effort traffic to a lower-priority class."

comments.content: Since we don't want received (inbound) traffic to starve the business-critical traffic, we can police (drop) those.

discussion.content: You always want to shape traffic outbound unless it is a very specific case.

Selected Answer: B
should be B
This should be D

choices.B: Configure the queuing default queue for shaping inbound and policing outbound.
choices.A: Configure the queuing default queue for shaping inbound and policing inbound.
choices.C: Configure the queuing default queue for shaping outbound and policing inbound.
choices.D: Configure the queuing default queue for shaping outbound and policing outbound.

questions.question_text: An engineer is designing a QoS solution for a customer. The customer's internet connection has a bandwidth of 10 Mbps. The design must ensure that traffic bursts of data do not exceed the bandwidth of the connection and that received traffic does not starve out business-critical traffic. Which solution must the engineer choose?

choices.D: supporting secure communication between network devices and control systems using TLS and HTTPS
choices.C: implementing secure server-client tunnels with RSA 2048 cipher encryption
choices.A: enabling RC6 data-level encryption with CRC check
choices.B: mandatory encryption of data at rest using the AES and RSA protocols

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
gRPC is based on TLS/HTTPS2

questions.question_text: Which security functionality does gRPC provide?

discussion.content:

VLAN must be at multiple switches so has to be a layer 2 design of which D is the best.

Selected Answer: D
Echo'ing rsb81 with a vote.
Answer is D

questions.question_text:
An engineer working for a service provider with an employee ID: 4604:68:004 prepared several designs for a traditional campus network. The design must allow the deployment of the same VLAN to any switch at the access layer and must support:
• fast convergence
• high availability
• resilience

Which design must be selected?

discussion.content:
Given answer is correct. 

"Note: The IETF and Native models for IOS XE use separate containers/models for operational data and configuration data, while the OpenConfig combines both config and operational data into the same container."

https://blogs.cisco.com/developer/which-yang-model-to-use

questions.question_text: When differentiating between IETF, OpenConfig, and Cisco native YANG models, how does the use of containers differ?

choices.B: OpenConfig uses one container for operational data and another container for configuration data, and IETF and Cisco native models use a single container for operational data and configuration data.
choices.D: IETF and Cisco native models use a single container for operational data and configuration data, and OpenConfig uses one container for operational data and another container for configuration data.
choices.C: Cisco native models use one container for operational data and another container for configuration data, and OpenConfig and IETF use a single container for operational data and configuration data.
choices.A: IETF and Cisco native models use one container for operational data and another container for configuration data, and OpenConfig uses a single container for operational data and configuration data.

questions.question_text: An engineer must connect a new remote site to an existing OSPF network. The new site consists of two low-end routers, one for WAN, and one for LAN. There is no demand for traffic to pass through this area. Which area type does the engineer choose to provide minimal router resource utilization, while still allowing for full connectivity to the rest of the network?

discussion.content: I this correct answer is C.

Selected Answer: C
Btw, there are STUB areas, STUBBY areas do not exist (if it does, I cannot find it on Cisco documentation).

Ans: D
A stubby area in OSPF is used to reduce router resource utilization and limit the size of the routing table while still allowing for full connectivity to the rest of the OSPF network. This choice is appropriate when you have no demand for traffic to pass through the area, as it blocks the type 5 external LSAs, thereby reducing the routing information and resources required in that specific area.

Selected Answer: D
The provided answer is correct the answer is D. 
- Stub Area will be able to talk to the rest of the network (This is a requirement) where as the TSA can't. 
- The WAN router IS NOT an ASBR, it is simply an ABR connected to the rest of the OSPF Network, it would of been an ASBR if EIGRP or a different routing protocol was running here. 
- Stub area also uses low resources, o tho TSA uses less but unfortunately it does not mee the (needs to reach the rest of the network requirement) where as Stubby Area does.

Selected Answer: D
D is Correct

Selected Answer: C
we need ASBR for WAN, and stub area does not have ASBR

C is better answer than D. 
 A stub area is an area in which advertisements of external routes are not allowed, reducing the size of the database. A totally stubby area (TSA) is a stub area in which summary link-state advertisement (type 3 LSAs) are not sent. A default summary LSA, with a prefix of 0.0.

Selected Answer: C
C correct

Selected Answer: C
totally stubby area inject 1 default route into the area, it should able to connect rest of the network with minimal resource used

Selected Answer: C
“There is no demand for traffic to pass through this area.” So we know from this that an NSSA or a totally not so stubby area is needed. NSSA’s or totally NSSA’s are only needed if routes are being injected into the OSPF domain. So A and B are not correct. 
C and D are both similar in that they both do not inject Type 5 LSA, which would keep router utilization down. However, if we desire to cut down on as many LSA’s as possible, which would then cut down on the router utilization due to the OSPF routers not having to run the SPF calculation, then answer C is MOST correct. A totally stubby area restricts not only type 5, but also type 4 and type 3 LSA’s. Since the requirement states “provide minimal resource utilization” answer C “totally stubby area” is correct.

Selected Answer: C
I think C - Totally Stubby Area is correct. Just a default into this new area is fine.
Why not A?
I think C as LSA type1 + type2 + Defaut required to minimise Router resources utilization -> total stub area
Sorry. Answer should be C as Stub area blocks external traffic
D is answer

Selected Answer: D
Answer is right D, 2 routers, means Layer 3 LSA's need to get in so the area knows how to reach routes on the LAN/ other Areas.

A totally stubby area is an area that is not able to accept LSA type 3 or 5 which contain routes from outside the OSPF domain and is not able to accept routes from outside the area; traffic is only able to exit the area via a default route (which is injected via the ABR).Jan 18, 2012
Totally stubby uses DR and wants total connectivity is would think D.
Why not totally stubby area C? I would expect that this setup need even less router resources.
